There is debate over whether the President can send forces into hostile situations abroad without congressional authorization. Congressional concern over this issue grew after the Korean conflict and during the Vietnam War. The War Powers Resolution (P.L. 93-148) was passed on November 7, 1973, to establish procedures for both branches of government to share decisions involving the use of armed forces in circumstances that could lead to hostilities. It aimed to limit the President's authority to deploy forces abroad without congressional approval while allowing flexibility to respond to emergencies.
